abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the
            Disaster Risk Mitigation and Adaptation Project for Albania
            was judged to be moderately satisfactory.  The Bank
            performance rating was moderately satisfactory and the
            borrower performance was satisfactory.  The risk to
            development outcome was rated substantial.  Several lessons
            were learned. Project preparation was not sufficient, which
            led to implementation delays in initial years. Establishing
            a Project Management Team (PMT) at the General Directorate
            of Civil Emergencies was one of the effectiveness
            conditions, but it took the Ministry of Interior about one
            year since project approval to establish the team. Moreover,
            none of the terms of reference for key studies and
            consultancy services was developed before project approval.
            Coordination of multiple agencies, despite the relatively
            small size of the project was complex with four independent
            components, each of which was implemented by a different
            agency. A more effective coordination mechanism should have
            been carefully thought through at project preparation and
            managed throughout project implementation.  Early on, the
            Government and the Bank should have paid more serious
            attention to the operational phases of various project
            activities to ensure effective operational arrangements
            after the project is completed.  Starting small is a less
            risky approach as major investments will take place only if
            the required capacity and other necessary arrangements are
            in place.  Finally, taking a regional approach to disaster
            risk management was a key lesson of the insurance component.
            The Albanian government managed to create the framework for
            reducing its fiscal risk exposure to natural disasters and
            at the same time secured access to affordable and innovative
            catastrophe insurance products.  A regional approach to
            disaster risk management can benefit all participating
            countries by enabling them to reach better quality outcomes
            at a much reduced cost per country.
